They only pay once to join and do not have to pay monthly, annual, or hidden costs.

Yes, every live session of the program is recorded, so you have the flexibility to attend the classes live or catch up asynchronously later using the recordings. This option is beneficial for those who may not be able to attend the live sessions due to time zone differences, scheduling conflicts, or personal reasons. The recorded sessions will be available for you to watch at your convenience, allowing you to learn at your own pace and review the content multiple times to solidify your understanding.

The cost to join the program is $500, and it includes lifetime access to the program, which includes 18 hours of live, interactive sessions, 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions, a final project with direct feedback, 100 coding assignments and practice questions, the source code of a working production system, a private community for collaboration, direct access to the instructor, lifetime access to every past and future cohort, and a program certificate upon completion. There are no monthly fees, annual fees, or hidden costs. Once you pay to join, you have immediate access to every past, present, and future cohort, and there is no pressure to complete the program as you can join later cohorts to benefit from future updates.

The costs associated with joining the program are as follows: $500, which is paid once to access the program for lifetime. There are no monthly fees, annual fees, or hidden costs after the initial payment. This includes access to all past, present, and future cohorts, live and recorded sessions, coding assignments, a final project with direct feedback, and a private community. The program certificate is earned upon completion.

The strategies mentioned for active learning in the course are uncertainty sampling and diversity sampling. These sampling strategies are used to determine which data points are most beneficial to label in order to improve model performance. Uncertainty sampling selects data points with high uncertainty, which are less confidently classified by the model. Diversity sampling selects data points that are diverse or representative of different regions of the input feature space that the model is unsure about. By using active learning, machine learning engineers can label fewer data points while still improving model performance and reducing the overall cost and time required for model training.

8. Willingness to put in the time and effort required to master the skills taught in the program, as it is not an easy but rewarding experience.

'Lifetime access' in the context of the program refers to the fact that students only need to pay once to join and gain immediate access to all past, present, and future iterations of the program. This means that they can participate in as many cohorts as they want without any additional fees or hidden costs. The program offers 18 hours of live, interactive sessions, 10 hours of coding instructions, a final project, 100 coding assignments, a working production system, a private community, direct access to the instructor, recorded sessions, office hours, and a program certificate upon completion. Students have the flexibility to attend live sessions or watch recorded versions at their convenience, and the earlier they join, the more time they have to prepare. This program is intended for technical professionals with programming experience, familiarity with basic machine learning terminology, and a desire to learn the fundamental principles and concepts behind building machine learning systems in a practical, hands-on setting.

The program's live sessions for building machine learning systems cover six topics:

1. How To Start (Almost) Any Project: This session will cover what makes production machine learning different from what is learned, critical questions to ask before starting any project, problem framing, the haystack principle, starting building, and data collection strategies.

2. Training Pipelines: This session will discuss how to train models using common frameworks like TensorFlow, Keras, and PyTorch.

3. Deployment: Topics will include how to deploy machine learning models in production, the AWS Elastic Beanstalk service for deploying containerized applications, and how to integrate machine learning models into applications.

4. Monitoring: This session will explore tools for monitoring machine learning models, best practices for doing health checks, and using Amazon CloudWatch for monitoring.

5. Inference: This session will cover techniques for scaling inference, batch processing, and serverless inference using AWS Lambda and Amazon SageMaker.

6. Performance Optimization: This session will discuss optimizing performance, choosing the right data structure, and using caching to improve performance.

The live sessions are interactive, allowing students to ask questions and interact with the instructor and other students in real-time. Students will also receive step-by-step coding instructions during the program. These coding sessions will help students build an end-to-end system from scratch, and assignments will provide ample practice opportunities. Additionally, the program includes the source code of a production system and access to a private community, direct feedback from the instructor, and a certificate upon completion.

The financial obligation to enroll in the program is a one-time payment of $500. This payment grants lifetime access to the program, which includes 18 hours of live sessions, 10 hours of coding instructions, a final project, 100 coding assignments and practice questions, the source code of a working production system, a private community, direct access to the instructor, access to all past and future cohorts, and a program certificate upon completion. There are no monthly, annual, or hidden fees required beyond this initial payment. Overall, this program offers a cost-effective option for technical professionals looking to develop their skills in machine learning.

Session 1 of the program, titled "How To Start (Almost) Any Project", is centered around practical skills and insights required for building production machine learning systems. The session highlights the differences between what one has learned in theory and what is needed in practice for production ML. It emphasizes the importance of framing problems accurately, using the right solutions, and asking critical questions before starting any project. The session touches upon the haystack principle for building successful applications, the first rule of ML engineering, and data collection strategies. It also introduces techniques for determining how much data is required and how to handle selection bias. The session emphasizes labeling data, its various techniques, and active learning using uncertainty and diversity sampling strategies. With this session, students can successfully initiate ML projects with a production-oriented perspective.

If you cannot attend the live sessions during the program, you can access recordings of them at any time through lifetime access, which is included in the program fee. This feature allows you to catch up on missed classes asynchronously at your convenience.

According to the provided context, some of the strategies for active learning that are highlighted in the course include uncertainty sampling and diversity sampling. These techniques are specifically mentioned in the context of active learning, which is discussed in Session 2 - How to Build a Model and further explored in Session 3 - Active Learning. The program also touches on the problem of selection bias and how to deal with it in this session. In addition, best practices for handling missing values using imputation techniques are also covered in this session, as well as the importance of producing homogeneous features using normalization and standardization for better model performance. The program emphasizes practical, hands-on learning with step-by-step coding instructions and a final project where students can receive direct feedback on their work. Overall, the course focuses on building machine learning systems that work in the real world, with best practices for tackling challenges related to building, evaluating, running, monitoring, and maintaining such systems.

The exact start date for the upcoming cohort of the 'Building Machine Learning Systems That Don't Suck' program is February 3, 2025. This program runs for three weeks, with live sessions taking place every Monday and Thursday at 10:00 AM EST. An optional learning session will be held on Wednesdays. Students can choose to attend the live sessions or watch the recorded sessions at a later time. This program is designed for students who have already gained some foundation in machine learning and are looking to build production-ready machine learning systems using Amazon SageMaker and open-source tools.

The course covers two active learning strategies, uncertainty sampling and diversity sampling, to address the problems of selection bias and data diversity. Uncertainty sampling involves selecting the most uncertain samples to label, which helps to reduce the number of required labels and improve model accuracy. Diversity sampling, on the other hand, involves selecting a diverse set of samples to label, which helps to ensure that the model is not overfit to a specific subset of the data. These strategies can be applied in the context of active learning to efficiently and effectively label large datasets for machine learning applications.

The program's Cohort 17 has a scheduled time slot of 10:00 AM EST, with live sessions taking place every Monday and Thursday for three weeks, from February 3 to February 20, 2025. The program syllabus includes a focus on practical experiences building machine learning systems that work in the real world, and while it does not specifically mention active learning or distributed training techniques as part of the schedule, the program's description mentions that students will learn how to create training, deployment, monitoring, and inference pipelines using Amazon SageMaker and open-source tools. This could potentially include learning about these techniques through the use of these platforms. Students who are particularly interested in these topics may want to reach out to the instructor, Santiago, for more information about how they will be covered in the program. Overall, the program provides opportunities for students to interact with the instructor and other students through live sessions, code walkthroughs, and Q&A sessions, allowing for flexibility in learning style and pace.

The cost to join the program is only a one-time payment, and there are no monthly, annual, or hidden fees. The fee includes lifetime access to the following resources:

1. 18 hours of live, interactive sessions focused on the first principles behind building machine learning systems.
2. 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions that teach students how to build an end-to-end system from scratch.
3. A final project where students can build a complete solution and receive direct feedback on their work.
4. 100 coding assignments and practice questions.
5. The complete source code of a working production system, which is yours to change and use as you see fit.
6. A private community where students can collaborate with people from different backgrounds.
7. Direct access to the instructor.
8. Lifetime access to every past and future cohort, allowing students to benefit from program updates and receive feedback and support from the community.
9. A program certificate upon completion.

Students paying for the program can enjoy these resources without any restrictions, even if they're beginners. Additionally, the lifetime access allows students to join later cohorts to benefit from updates without any added pressure to complete the program.

Upon joining the machine learning program, you receive resources and materials that address the topics of handling selection bias and data labeling, including:

1. Session 2 - How to Build a Model: In this session, you learn about how to deal with selection bias and labeling data. Specifically, you'll learn about human annotations, natural labels, and weak supervision, as well as active learning using the uncertainty and diversity sampling strategies.

2. Step-by-step coding instructions: There are 10 hours of coding instructions provided in the program, some of which cover topics related to labeling and handling selection bias. For example, you'll learn about labeled and unlabeled data, semi-supervised learning, and data augmentation techniques to generate more labeled data.

3. Final project: The final project requires you to build a complete machine learning solution, and potential project ideas may involve tackling selection bias or labeling data issues.

In Session 2 of the course on the Machine Learning School Website, the following topics related to feature engineering and hyperparameter tuning are covered:

1. The role of data cleaning and feature engineering to build better models.
2. Turning data into numbers using vectorization techniques.
3. Producing homogeneous features using normalization and standardization.
4. Handling and interpreting missing values using imputation techniques.
5. Choosing the best model to solve any problem. Random baselines and the zero-rule algorithm. How to use overfitting to build models that don't suck.
6. Hyperparameter tuning and experiment tracking.
7. Measuring the quality of your holdout set.

These topics will provide practical skills and insights into how to improve feature engineering and hyperparameter tuning for building better models in machine learning.

The program primarily offers a practical, hands-on approach to learning machine learning. Participants will have access to live, interactive sessions for 18 hours, where they will learn the first principles behind building machine learning systems. They will also receive 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions for building an end-to-end system from scratch. Additionally, participants will complete a final project and receive direct feedback on their work. There will be 100 coding assignments and practice questions provided, as well as a private community for collaboration with other participants from diverse backgrounds. Direct access to the instructor will be available, and participants will have lifetime access to every past and future cohort of the program. The program certificate will be awarded upon completion, and participants will receive the entire source code of a working production system that they can modify and use as they see fit. The program is not an introduction to machine learning and is better suited for those with prior knowledge in the field, but the live sessions will be recorded for those who cannot attend them live. The lifetime access provides flexibility for participants to complete the program at their own pace, regardless of any outside pressures or constraints. The instructor, Santiago, has over two decades of experience in building and scaling enterprise software and machine learning systems for various clients. He started the program in March 2023 and has already engaged thousands of participants.

Benefits:
1. Lifetime access to the program, including all past and future cohorts, without monthly, annual, or hidden fees.
2. Six live sessions, recorded for asynchronous viewing, covering practical skills and insights for building machine learning systems.
3. 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions, providing hands-on experience.
4. 100 coding assignments and practice questions.
5. Access to the complete source code of a working production system.
6. Private community for collaboration with peers from diverse backgrounds.
7. Direct access to the instructor.
8. Program certificate upon completion.

Topics covered in the first session:
1. Understanding the difference between production machine learning and what has been learned.
2. Critical questions to ask before starting any project.
3. The strategy to solve the right problem using the right solution.
4. Problem framing, inversion, and the haystack principle for building successful applications.
5. The first rule of machine learning engineering and how to start building.
6. Data collection strategies.
7. "The elseif Question: How Do You
Explore Uncertainty?" (from the book Machine Learning at Google Scale by Jeff Dean, script by Santiago Pug Platform)

The next cohort is scheduled to start on February 3, 2025, and will run for three weeks with live, interactive sessions, step-by-step coding instructions, and a final project where students will build a complete solution and receive direct feedback on their work. The course also includes coding assignments, practice questions, a private community, access to the instructor, and lifetime access to every past and future cohort.

The Machine Learning School program offers practical skills in building machine learning systems, specifically in best practices for tackling challenges such as designing, writing code, building, evaluating, running, monitoring, and maintaining systems in real-world scenarios. The program emphasizes the practical aspect of learning, with 18 hours of live, interactive sessions, 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions, a final project, and 100 coding assignments and practice questions. The program also includes direct feedback on work, a private community, direct access to the instructor, and lifetime access to every past, present, and future cohort. One unique aspect of the program is the focus on unlearning misconceptions about machine learning and providing real-world examples and years of experience. Another unique aspect is the ability to benefit from updates in future cohorts without having to pay again for lifetime access. Overall, the program aims to provide practical skills and insights into building machine learning systems that work in the real world.

Answer: The course discusses the strategies of uncertainty sampling and diversity sampling for active learning. For handling missing values, the course covers imputation techniques for interpreting missing values.

The cost structure for joining the machine learning program is as follows: there is a one-time joining fee, and there are no monthly, annual, or hidden costs. This program is designed for technical professionals with experience in writing code and basic knowledge of machine learning terminology. It is suitable for software engineers, data scientists, data analysts, machine learning engineers, technical managers, and anyone else who wants to use machine learning to solve real-world problems. The program offers lifetime access, with live sessions, coding instructions, a final project, coding assignments, source code, community access, direct instructor access, access to past and future cohorts, and a program certificate upon completion. The commitment required is at least two to four hours per week for the live sessions or to catch up using recordings at a later time. Beginners can also benefit from the program but should expect sessions to go faster than optimal for them. The instructor, Santiago, has over two decades of experience building and scaling enterprise software and machine learning systems, having worked with major clients such as Disney, Boston Dynamics, IBM, and NextEra Energy. If you have any further questions, you can reach out to the instructor on social media.

The program consists of live sessions on Mondays and Thursdays for two hours each, as well as individual work on Tuesdays and Fridays. Optional office hours are held on Wednesdays. The program is not designed for beginners, as basic machine learning terminology is expected. However, prior experience writing code in any language is necessary. The cost to join is $500, which grants lifetime access with no monthly, annual, or hidden fees. Past, present, and future cohorts are included in this access, and new iterations continually improve the program. The program is intended for technical professionals, including software engineers, data scientists, data analysts, machine learning engineers, technical managers, and anyone who wants to use machine learning to solve real-world problems. The instructor, Santiago, is a machine learning engineer with over two decades of experience creating enterprise software and machine learning systems for clients such as Disney, Boston Dynamics, IBM, Dell, G4S, Anheuser-Busch, and NextEra Energy. Live sessions are recorded for those unable to attend in real-time.

Answer: You will gain practical skills and insights to build machine learning systems that work in the real world. This program will help you unlearn what you think machine learning is and provide you with years of experience and real-world examples. You will learn best practices to tackle the most significant challenges machine learning engineers face, such as building, evaluating, running, monitoring, and maintaining machine learning systems in real-world scenarios. You will design and write the code to build an end-to-end machine learning system starting from scratch, and you will receive direct feedback on your work. The program also includes 18 hours of live, interactive sessions, 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions, 100 coding assignments, the complete source code of a production system, a private community, and direct access to the instructor. Additionally, you can join past and future cohorts and receive a program certificate upon completion.

Here are the details of the machine learning program mentioned in the context provided:

1. Program duration: The program consists of six live sessions, each lasting for 3 hours, making a total of 18 hours. There are also 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions and 100 coding assignments.

2. Program structure: The sessions are a mix of interactive discussions and practical coding sessions. The focus is on learning the first principles of building machine learning systems, the critical questions to ask before starting any project, and strategies for collecting data.

3. Program access: Once you join the program, you have lifetime access to all past, present, and future cohorts. There are no monthly or annual fees, and there are no hidden costs. The program costs $500, and payment is made only once.

4. Program benefits: Apart from the sessions and coding instructions, the program includes the complete source code of a production system, a final project, access to a private community, direct access to the instructor, a program certificate upon completion, and updates to the program.

5. Target audience: The program is designed for beginners to machine learning, but experienced machine learning engineers will also benefit from the first principles approach. The instructor recommends taking a real-world project and applying the techniques learned during the program.

6. Testimonials: The program has received positive feedback from learners, with some describing it as one of the best online courses they've taken. One student called the instructor a terrific teacher, and another recommended the program, stating that it's worth ten times the cost.

7. Instructor: Santiago is the instructor of the program. He has over two decades of experience building and scaling enterprise software and machine learning systems for clients such as Disney, Boston Dynamics, and IBM. He started the program in March 2023.

Answer: The upcoming cohort for "Building Machine Learning Systems That Don't Suck" starts on February 3, 2025. The program consists of 18 hours of live, interactive training spread over 3 weeks. Live sessions will take place every Monday and Thursday at 10:00 AM EST, and office hours will be hosted on Wednesdays. The sooner you join, the more time you have to prepare, as lifetime access is included with the one-time payment of $500. Every session is recorded, and you can attend live or watch the recorded version later. The program covers designing, building, deploying, and scaling machine learning systems to solve real-world problems using Amazon SageMaker and open-source tools, with a focus on practical, real-life examples and case studies. Additionally, the program is designed for advanced learners who already know the basics of machine learning and want to learn how to create production-ready systems that work in the real world.
